Timestamps

Detailed Description

A timestamp contains the information to certify that some data existed in a given form at some given time in the past.

GuardTime timestamps are internally represented in ASN.1 and serialized and stored in DER-encoding.

A GuardTime timestamp is instanciated by:

  • creating a timestamp request from a hash value using GTTimestamp_prepareTimestampRequest() and sending that request to a timesource, then using GTTimestamp_createTimestamp() to create a timestamp from the timesource response;
  • creating a timestamp extension request from an existing timestamp by using GTTimestamp_prepareExtensionRequest() and sending that request to an extender, then using GTTimestamp_createExtendedTimestamp() to create an extended timestamp from the extender response;
  • loading an existing DER-encoded timestamp using GTTimestamp_DERDecode().

To save a timestamp, use GTTimestamp_getDEREncoded() and write the resulting byte array to a file or store it in some other applicable way.

A timestamp directly only exposes the hash algorithm which was used to calculate the hash sum from which the timestamp was created (use GTTimestamp_getAlgorithm() to get that information). All other properties, such as whether the timestamp is valid, when it was issued, etc are exposed by creating a GTVerificationInfo object using GTTimestamp_verify().

See also:
Publications, Verification

The functions described in this group are declared in the gt_base.h header file and implemented in the libgtbase library. For more implementation and usage details, see the notes for the header file.

Typedef Documentation

typedef struct GTTimestamp_st GTTimestamp

This opaque structure represents a timestamp. Use the GTTimestamp_verify(), GTTimestamp_getAlgorithm(), GTTimestamp_isExtended(), GTTimestamp_isEarlierThan() functions to extract details from it.

Function Documentation

int GTTimestamp_createExtendedTimestamp ( const GTTimestamp *  timestamp,
const void *  response,
size_t  response_length,
GTTimestamp **  extended_timestamp 
)

Creates an extended timestamp based on timestamp and extension response.

Parameters:
timestamp(in) - Timestamp that is to be extended.
response(in) - Pointer to the buffer containing encoded extendion response.
response_length(in) - Size of the buffer pointed by response.
extended_timestamp(out) - Pointer that will receive pointer to the extended timestamp.
Returns:
status code (GT_OK, when operation succeeded, otherwise an error code). Semantic errors can be:
  • GT_CANNOT_EXTEND - The historyImprint field of timestamp is inconsistent with the history.dataChain field of response.
int GTTimestamp_createTimestamp ( const void *  response,
size_t  response_length,
GTTimestamp **  timestamp 
)

Creates a timestamp from response data.

Parameters:
response(in) - Pointer to the buffer containing encoded response.
response_length(in) - Size of the buffer pointed by response.
timestamp(out) - Pointer that will receive pointer to the created timestamp.
Returns:
status code (GT_OK, when operation succeeded, otherwise an error code).
int GTTimestamp_DERDecode ( const void *  data,
size_t  data_length,
GTTimestamp **  timestamp 
)

Decodes a timestamp from given byte string.

Parameters:
data(in) - Pointer to buffer containing DER-encoded timestamp.
data_length(in) - Size of buffer pointed by data.
timestamp(out) - Pointer that will receive pointer to decoded timestamp.
Returns:
status code (GT_OK, when operation succeeded, otherwise an error code).

Parameters:
timestamp(in) - GTTimestamp object that is to be freed.

Encodes a timestamp into byte string.

Parameters:

data(out) - Pointer that will receive pointer to the DER-encoded timestamp.
data_length(out) - Pointer that will receive length of DER-encoded timestamp
Returns:
status code (GT_OK, when operation succeeded, otherwise an error code).
int GTTimestamp_isEarlierThan ( const GTTimestamp *  this_timestamp,
const GTTimestamp *  that_timestamp 
)

Compares temporal order of two timestamps, trying to determine if this_timestamp was issued earlier that_timestamp. Note that if this_timestamp is not earlier than that_timestamp, then this does not necessarily mean that that_timestamp is earlier than this_timestamp. It is possible that the temporal order of two timestamps cannot be determined.

Both timestamps must be successfully verified if result of this comparison is to have any meaningful value.

Returns:
  • GT_EARLIER, if this_timestamp is earlier than that_timestamp.
  • GT_NOT_EARLIER, if this_timestamp cannot be proved to be earlier than that_timestamp.
  • error code, if there was an error when performing the comparison.
int GTTimestamp_isExtended ( const GTTimestamp *  timestamp )

Checks if the given timestamp is extended.

Parameters:
timestamp(in) - Pointer to timestamp.
Returns:
  • GT_EXTENDED, if timestamp is a hash-linked one.
  • GT_NOT_EXTENDED, if timestamp is an PKI-signed one.
  • error code, if there was an error when performing the check.
int GTTimestamp_prepareExtensionRequest ( const GTTimestamp *  timestamp,
unsigned char **  request_data,
size_t *  request_length 
)

Prepares an encoded timestamp extension request that can be used to extend given timestamp to another timestamp.

Parameters:
timestamp(in) - Timestamp that is to be extended.
request_data(out) - Pointer that will receive pointer to the DER-encoded timestamp extension request.
request_length(out) - Pointer that will receive length of DER-encoded timestamp extension request.
Returns:
status code (GT_OK, when operation succeeded, otherwise an error code).
int GTTimestamp_prepareTimestampRequest ( const GTDataHash *  data_hash,
unsigned char **  request_data,
size_t *  request_length 
)

Prepares an encoded timestamp request.

Parameters:
data_hash(in) - Pointer to the data hash. The hash computation must be closed before the hash object can be passed to this function.
request_data(out) - Pointer that will receive pointer to the DER-encoded timestamp request.
request_length(out) - Pointer to the variable that receives length of DER-encoded timestamp request.
Returns:
status code (GT_OK, when operation succeeded, otherwise an error code).
